title: Mingya HUANG
text:
About Me
I am a Ph.D. Candidate of Quantitative Methods in the Department of Educational Psychology at UW–Madison. My research involves leveraging Bayesian statistics and machine learning methods to tackle problems in social and behavioral sciences. Currently, my work focuses on Bayesian nonparametrics and its application in large-scale assessments.


Research Interests

Bayesian Statistics
Machine Learning
Multilevel Modeling
Causal Inference

title: Publications

Huang, M., David Kaplan (2024). [In press] Predictive Performance of Bayesian Stacking in Multilevel Education Data. Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics. [preprint] [code]
Garbacz, S. A., Stormshak, E. A., McIntyre, L. L., Bolt, D., & Huang, M. (2022). Family-Centered Prevention During Elementary School to Reduce Growth in Emotional and Behavior Problems. Journal of Emotional and Behavioral Disorders, 10634266221143720. [paper]

Kaplan, D., & Huang, M. (2021). Bayesian probabilistic forecasting with large-scale educational trend data: a case study using NAEP. Large-scale Assessments in Education, 9(1), 1-31. [paper]

title: Mingya HUANG
text:
I am a Ph.D. student in Quantitative Methods working with Dr. David Kaplan in the Department of Educational Psychology and Dr. Sameer Deshpande in the Department of Statistics at University of Wisconsin-Madison. Prior to that, I graduated with an M.S. in Quantitative Methods under the supervision of Dr. Carolyn Anderson at University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. I got my undergraduate degree in Education and Psychology at University of Macao.

My research involves developing Bayesian statistics as well as Machine Learing methods for problems in education, psychology, and social science researches. Currently, my work focuses on Bayesian nonparametrics and its application in large-scale clustered data.



Bayesian Statistics
Machine Learning
Hierarchical Clustering
Causal Inference

title: Mingya HUANG
text:
News

September 2024: Presented research on Bayesian nonparametrics at the International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML).
July 2024: Published a new paper on Bayesian additive regression trees in the Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics.
May 2024: Awarded the Outstanding Graduate Student Researcher Award by the Department of Educational Psychology at UW–Madison.
March 2024: Invited to give a guest lecture on Applied Bayesian Statistics at Stanford University.
